Define the concept and mathematical representation of a subset and a nonempty subset.
Calculate the reciprocal of an element in a set.
Express the product of reciprocals for elements in a single subset.
Understand the implication and operation of taking the sum over all nonempty subsets.
Employ combinatorial techniques or formulas to consider all possible subsets and orderings.
Derive the general form which relates to the binomial theorem or geometric series to simplify the expression.
Finally, express the sum as a function of n, showing its dependency on the number of elements in the initial set.

1: Define the concept and mathematical representation of a subset and a nonempty subset.
2: Calculate the reciprocal of an element in a set.
3: Express the product of reciprocals for elements in a single subset.
4: Understand the implication and operation of taking the sum over all nonempty subsets.
5: Employ combinatorial techniques or formulas to consider all possible subsets and orderings.
6: Derive the general form which relates to the binomial theorem or geometric series to simplify the expression.
7: Finally, express the sum as a function of n, showing its dependency on the number of elements in the initial set.

Sum all contributions from unique elements of the set {1, 2, ..., n} to the overall sum.
Use properties of geometric or arithmetic series to simplify the calculations, if applicable.
Express the result in terms of n using combinatorial identities or simplifications.
